page.text: P20 profile:
Agenda 2030 includes the specific commitment to Leave
No One Behind. Together with Sustainable Development
Goal 10 to reduce inequality, this requires faster than average
progress for the poorest. The test is whether the gap between
the poorest 20% of people (the P20) and everyone else
is reducing or getting wider.
The P20 Initiative uses data to show whether the poorest 20%
of people are getting their fair share of attention, investment
and opportunity. It uses three bellwether indicators of progress:
income, nutrition and civil registration and it promotes all data
being disaggregated by Income Quintile, Gender, Geography,
Age and Disability.
This profile provides key available data about the status
of the P20 in Afghanistan.
NA people in Afghanistan are among
the poorest 20% of the world’s population – the
global P20. That is NA of the total population
and they live on less than $2.54 a day.
The national P20 – the poorest 20% of people
within Afghanistan – live on between $[XX]
and $[XX] a day compared with an average $[XX]
for the rest of the population.
Source: Development Initiatives based on PovcalNet
In 2000 the gap between the P20 and everyone
else in Afghanistan was $[0.00] and in 2013
Source: Development Initiatives based on PovcalNet
Nutrition is fundamental to the ability to learn
and earn. Children who experience poor nutrition
can suffer lifelong disadvantage as a result.
In Afghanistan, [X]% of under five year
olds experienced stunting. In the P20 [XX]%
experienced stunting compared with [XX]%
of the rest of the population.
Source: Development Initiatives based on UNICEF-WHO joint child
malnutrition estimates
Civil Registration means people count and
have rights. Worldwide around 71% of children
are birth registered. If you are born into the
poorest 20% of people you are much less likely
to have your birth registered.
In Afghanistan [XX]% of births in the P20
are registered compared [XX]% in the rest of
the population.
Birth registration rates in Afghanistan
have [increased/decreased].
Source: Development Initiatives based on World Bank World Development Indicators:
Completeness of birth registration %
Education is fundamental to a person’s
life chances.
In Afghanistan [XX]% of people have
completed secondary school education.
[XX]% of people in the P20 have completed
a secondary education compared with [XX]%
of the rest of the population.
Source: Demographic Health Surveys (DHS)
Poor health plays a major part in keeping people
in poverty. If you are among the P20 you are more
likely to suffer from preventable diseases and
to die earlier.
In Afghanistan the Under Five Mortality rate
is [XX] per 1,000 live births.
The under five mortality rate among the P20
is [XX] per 1,000 live births compared with [XX]
per 1,000 live births for the rest of the population.
Source: Development Initiatives based on Demographic Health Surveys (DHS)
Year of latest available data: 2013 (2011 $PPP)
Based on latest available data which varies between countries – see original source

P20 profile:
Agenda 2030 includes the specific commitment to Leave
No One Behind. Together with Sustainable Development
Goal 10 to reduce inequality, this requires faster than average
progress for the poorest. The test is whether the gap between
the poorest 20% of people (the P20) and everyone else
is reducing or getting wider.
The P20 Initiative uses data to show whether the poorest 20%
of people are getting their fair share of attention, investment
and opportunity. It uses three bellwether indicators of progress:
income, nutrition and civil registration and it promotes all data
being disaggregated by Income Quintile, Gender, Geography,
Age and Disability.
This profile provides key available data about the status
of the P20 in Canada.
238,031 people in Canada are among
the poorest 20% of the world’s population – the
global P20. That is 1% of the total population
and they live on less than $2.54 a day.
The national P20 – the poorest 20% of people
within Canada – live on between $[XX]
and $[XX] a day compared with an average $[XX]
for the rest of the population.
Source: Development Initiatives based on PovcalNet
In 2000 the gap between the P20 and everyone
else in Canada was $[0.00] and in 2013
Source: Development Initiatives based on PovcalNet
In Canada [XX]% of adults are obese.
Source: Development Initiatives based on NCD Risk Factor Collaboration 2017
Education is fundamental to a person’s
life chances.
In Canada [XX]% of people have
completed secondary school education.
Source: Development Initiatives based on UNESCO Institute for Statistics 2018
Data is not available that allows us to disaggregate
secondary school completion based on income
and therefore we are unable to see completion
rates for the P20 versus the rest of the population
in this country.
Poor health plays a major part in keeping people
in poverty. If you are among the P20 you are more
likely to suffer from preventable diseases and
to die earlier.
In Canada the under five mortality
rate is [XX] per 1,000 live births.
Data is not available that allows us to disaggregate
under five mortality based on income and
therefore we are unable to see this information
for the P20 versus the rest of the population.
Source: Development Initiatives based on World Bank World Development Indicators
Year of latest available data: 2013 (2011 $PPP)

text.b: percentage who have completed secondary education

P20 profile:
Agenda 2030 includes the specific commitment to Leave

79,746 people in Cape Verde are among

The national P20 – the poorest 20% of people
within Cape Verde – live on between $[XX]
and $[XX] a day compared with an average $[XX]
for the rest of the population.
Source: Development Initiatives based on PovcalNet
In 2000 the gap between the P20 and everyone
else in Cape Verde was $[0.00] and in 2013
Source: Development Initiatives based on PovcalNet
Nutrition is fundamental to the ability to learn
and earn. Children who experience poor nutrition
can suffer lifelong disadvantage as a result.
In Cape Verde, [X]% of under five year
olds experienced stunting. In the P20 [XX]%
experienced stunting compared with [XX]%
of the rest of the population.
Source: Development Initiatives based on UNICEF-WHO joint child
malnutrition estimates
Civil Registration means people count and
have rights. Worldwide around 71% of children
are birth registered. If you are born into the
poorest 20% of people you are much less likely
to have your birth registered.
In Cape Verde [XX]% of births in the P20
are registered compared [XX]% in the rest of
the population.
Birth registration rates in Cape Verde
have [increased/decreased].
Source: Development Initiatives based on World Bank World Development Indicators:
Completeness of birth registration %
Education is fundamental to a person’s
life chances.
In Cape Verde [XX]% of people have
completed secondary school education.
[XX]% of people in the P20 have completed
a secondary education compared with [XX]%
of the rest of the population.
Source: Demographic Health Surveys (DHS)
Poor health plays a major part in keeping people
in poverty. If you are among the P20 you are more
likely to suffer from preventable diseases and
to die earlier.
In Cape Verde the Under Five Mortality rate
is [XX] per 1,000 live births.
The under five mortality rate among the P20
is [XX] per 1,000 live births compared with [XX]
per 1,000 live births for the rest of the population.
Source: Development Initiatives based on Demographic Health Surveys (DHS)
Year of latest available data: 2013 (2011 $PPP)

P20 profile:
Agenda 2030 includes the specific commitment to Leave
No One Behind. Together with Sustainable Development
Goal 10 to reduce inequality, this requires faster than average
progress for the poorest. The test is whether the gap between
the poorest 20% of people (the P20) and everyone else
is reducing or getting wider.
The P20 Initiative uses data to show whether the poorest 20%
of people are getting their fair share of attention, investment
and opportunity. It uses three bellwether indicators of progress:
income, nutrition and civil registration and it promotes all data
being disaggregated by Income Quintile, Gender, Geography,
Age and Disability.
This profile provides key available data about the status
of the P20 in Finland.
0 people in Finland are among
the poorest 20% of the world’s population – the
global P20. That is 0% of the total population
and they live on less than $2.54 a day.
The national P20 – the poorest 20% of people
within Finland – live on between $[XX]
and $[XX] a day compared with an average $[XX]
for the rest of the population.
Source: Development Initiatives based on PovcalNet
In 2000 the gap between the P20 and everyone
else in Finland was $[0.00] and in 2013
Source: Development Initiatives based on PovcalNet
In Finland [XX]% of adults are obese.
Source: Development Initiatives based on NCD Risk Factor Collaboration 2017
Education is fundamental to a person’s
life chances.
In Finland [XX]% of people have
completed secondary school education.
Source: Development Initiatives based on UNESCO Institute for Statistics 2018
Data is not available that allows us to disaggregate
secondary school completion based on income
and therefore we are unable to see completion
rates for the P20 versus the rest of the population
in this country.
Poor health plays a major part in keeping people
in poverty. If you are among the P20 you are more
likely to suffer from preventable diseases and
to die earlier.
In Finland the under five mortality
rate is [XX] per 1,000 live births.
Data is not available that allows us to disaggregate
under five mortality based on income and
therefore we are unable to see this information
for the P20 versus the rest of the population.
Source: Development Initiatives based on World Bank World Development Indicators
Year of latest available data: 2013 (2011 $PPP)

Goal 10 to reduce inequality, this requires faster than average
progress for the poorest. The test is whether the gap between
the poorest 20% of people (the P20) and everyone else
is reducing or getting wider.
The P20 Initiative uses data to show whether the poorest 20%
of people are getting their fair share of attention, investment
and opportunity. It uses three bellwether indicators of progress:
income, nutrition and civil registration and it promotes all data
being disaggregated by Income Quintile, Gender, Geography,
Age and Disability.
This profile provides key available data about the status
of the P20 in Liberia.
2,594,489 people in Liberia are among
the poorest 20% of the world’s population – the
global P20. That is 60% of the total population
and they live on less than $2.54 a day.
The national P20 – the poorest 20% of people
within Liberia – live on between $[XX]
and $[XX] a day compared with an average $[XX]
for the rest of the population.
Source: Development Initiatives based on PovcalNet
In 2000 the gap between the P20 and everyone
else in Liberia was $[0.00] and in 2013
Source: Development Initiatives based on PovcalNet
Nutrition is fundamental to the ability to learn
and earn. Children who experience poor nutrition
can suffer lifelong disadvantage as a result.
In Liberia, [X]% of under five year
olds experienced stunting. In the P20 [XX]%
experienced stunting compared with [XX]%
of the rest of the population.
Source: Development Initiatives based on UNICEF-WHO joint child
malnutrition estimates
Civil Registration means people count and
have rights. Worldwide around 71% of children
are birth registered. If you are born into the
poorest 20% of people you are much less likely
to have your birth registered.
In Liberia [XX]% of births in the P20
are registered compared [XX]% in the rest of
the population.
Birth registration rates in Liberia
have [increased/decreased].
Source: Development Initiatives based on World Bank World Development Indicators:
Completeness of birth registration %
Education is fundamental to a person’s
life chances.
In Liberia [XX]% of people have
completed secondary school education.
[XX]% of people in the P20 have completed
a secondary education compared with [XX]%
of the rest of the population.
Source: Demographic Health Surveys (DHS)
Poor health plays a major part in keeping people
in poverty. If you are among the P20 you are more
likely to suffer from preventable diseases and
to die earlier.
In Liberia the Under Five Mortality rate
is [XX] per 1,000 live births.
The under five mortality rate among the P20
is [XX] per 1,000 live births compared with [XX]
per 1,000 live births for the rest of the population.
Source: Development Initiatives based on Demographic Health Surveys (DHS)

Agenda 2030 includes the specific commitment to Leave
No One Behind. Together with Sustainable Development
Goal 10 to reduce inequality, this requires faster than average
progress for the poorest. The test is whether the gap between
the poorest 20% of people (the P20) and everyone else
is reducing or getting wider.
The P20 Initiative uses data to show whether the poorest 20%
of people are getting their fair share of attention, investment
and opportunity. It uses three bellwether indicators of progress:
income, nutrition and civil registration and it promotes all data
being disaggregated by Income Quintile, Gender, Geography,
Age and Disability.
This profile provides key available data about the status
of the P20 in Namibia.
729,327 people in Namibia are among
the poorest 20% of the world’s population – the
global P20. That is 31% of the total population
and they live on less than $2.54 a day.
The national P20 – the poorest 20% of people
within Namibia – live on between $[XX]
and $[XX] a day compared with an average $[XX]
for the rest of the population.

Source: Development Initiatives based on PovcalNet

can suffer lifelong disadvantage as a result.

of the rest of the population.

malnutrition estimates
Civil Registration means people count and
have rights. Worldwide around 71% of children
are birth registered. If you are born into the
poorest 20% of people you are much less likely
to have your birth registered.

are registered compared [XX]% in the rest of
the population.

completed secondary school education.
[XX]% of people in the P20 have completed
a secondary education compared with [XX]%
of the rest of the population.
Source: Demographic Health Surveys (DHS)

in poverty. If you are among the P20 you are more
likely to suffer from preventable diseases and
to die earlier.

is [XX] per 1,000 live births.

P20 profile:
Agenda 2030 includes the specific commitment to Leave
No One Behind. Together with Sustainable Development
Goal 10 to reduce inequality, this requires faster than average
progress for the poorest. The test is whether the gap between
the poorest 20% of people (the P20) and everyone else
is reducing or getting wider.
The P20 Initiative uses data to show whether the poorest 20%
of people are getting their fair share of attention, investment
and opportunity. It uses three bellwether indicators of progress:
income, nutrition and civil registration and it promotes all data
being disaggregated by Income Quintile, Gender, Geography,
Age and Disability.
This profile provides key available data about the status
of the P20 in Sweden.
47,098 people in Sweden are among
the poorest 20% of the world’s population – the
global P20. That is 0% of the total population
and they live on less than $2.54 a day.
The national P20 – the poorest 20% of people
within Sweden – live on between $[XX]
and $[XX] a day compared with an average $[XX]
for the rest of the population.
Source: Development Initiatives based on PovcalNet
In 2000 the gap between the P20 and everyone
else in Sweden was $[0.00] and in 2013
Source: Development Initiatives based on PovcalNet
In Sweden [XX]% of adults are obese.
Source: Development Initiatives based on NCD Risk Factor Collaboration 2017
Education is fundamental to a person’s
life chances.
In Sweden [XX]% of people have
completed secondary school education.
Source: Development Initiatives based on UNESCO Institute for Statistics 2018
Data is not available that allows us to disaggregate
secondary school completion based on income
and therefore we are unable to see completion
rates for the P20 versus the rest of the population
in this country.
Poor health plays a major part in keeping people
in poverty. If you are among the P20 you are more
likely to suffer from preventable diseases and
to die earlier.
In Sweden the under five mortality
rate is [XX] per 1,000 live births.
Data is not available that allows us to disaggregate
under five mortality based on income and
therefore we are unable to see this information
for the P20 versus the rest of the population.
Source: Development Initiatives based on World Bank World Development Indicators
Year of latest available data: 2013 (2011 $PPP)

No One Behind. Together with Sustainable Development

progress for the poorest. The test is whether the gap between
the poorest 20% of people (the P20) and everyone else
is reducing or getting wider.
The P20 Initiative uses data to show whether the poorest 20%
of people are getting their fair share of attention, investment
and opportunity. It uses three bellwether indicators of progress:
income, nutrition and civil registration and it promotes all data
being disaggregated by Income Quintile, Gender, Geography,
Age and Disability.
This profile provides key available data about the status
of the P20 in Zimbabwe.
4,197,776 people in Zimbabwe are among
the poorest 20% of the world’s population – the
global P20. That is 28% of the total population
and they live on less than $2.54 a day.
The national P20 – the poorest 20% of people
within Zimbabwe – live on between $[XX]
and $[XX] a day compared with an average $[XX]
for the rest of the population.
Source: Development Initiatives based on PovcalNet
In 2000 the gap between the P20 and everyone
else in Zimbabwe was $[0.00] and in 2013
Source: Development Initiatives based on PovcalNet
Nutrition is fundamental to the ability to learn
and earn. Children who experience poor nutrition
can suffer lifelong disadvantage as a result.
In Zimbabwe, [X]% of under five year
olds experienced stunting. In the P20 [XX]%
experienced stunting compared with [XX]%
of the rest of the population.
Source: Development Initiatives based on UNICEF-WHO joint child
malnutrition estimates
Civil Registration means people count and
have rights. Worldwide around 71% of children
are birth registered. If you are born into the
poorest 20% of people you are much less likely
to have your birth registered.
In Zimbabwe [XX]% of births in the P20
are registered compared [XX]% in the rest of
the population.
Birth registration rates in Zimbabwe
have [increased/decreased].
Source: Development Initiatives based on World Bank World Development Indicators:
Completeness of birth registration %
Education is fundamental to a person’s
life chances.
In Zimbabwe [XX]% of people have
completed secondary school education.
[XX]% of people in the P20 have completed
a secondary education compared with [XX]%
of the rest of the population.
Source: Demographic Health Surveys (DHS)
Poor health plays a major part in keeping people
in poverty. If you are among the P20 you are more
likely to suffer from preventable diseases and
to die earlier.
In Zimbabwe the Under Five Mortality rate
is [XX] per 1,000 live births.
The under five mortality rate among the P20
is [XX] per 1,000 live births compared with [XX]
per 1,000 live births for the rest of the population.
Source: Development Initiatives based on Demographic Health Surveys (DHS)
Year of latest available data: 2013 (2011 $PPP)
